alert.note: Alert for Brazoria; Fort Bend; Wharton (Texas) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 15 at 6:34PM CDT until further notice by NWS Houston - Galveston
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Texas... Lake Creek at Sendera Ranch Road affecting Montgomery County. San Bernard River near Boling affecting Fort Bend, Wharton and Brazoria Counties. Sandy Creek near Cordele affecting Jackson, Wharton and Colorado Counties. Lavaca River near Edna affecting Jackson County. For the West Fork San Jacinto River...including Sendera Ranch Road, Humble...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the San Bernard River...including East Bernard, Boling...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Sandy Creek...including Cordele...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Lavaca River...including Edna...Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...San Bernard River near Boling. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 22.0 feet, Moderate lowland flooding begins upstream from the gage with significant backwater flooding up Peach Creek in Wharton County inundating low lying areas. Minor backwater flooding up Snake Creek in Fort Bend County begins. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:15 AM CDT Monday the stage was 19.4 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:15 AM CDT Monday was 19.4 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 21.4 feet this evening. It will then fall Thursday evening. It will rise to 19.1 feet early Friday morning. It will then fall again but remain above flood stage. - Flood stage is 18.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 21.4 feet on 12/22/1987. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (7 pm CDT) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Tue Wed Thu San Bernard River Boling 18.0 19.4 Mon 3 am CDT 20.2 21.5 21.3 &&
info.instruction: Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued Tuesday morning at 645 AM CDT.
